Expectation1: Attending children's school events and activities
Situation1: Children are about to finish school, and the mother should pick them up
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: While traveling, only a small vendor known to be kosher-certified is within reach for the next meal.
Story: I glance at the clock on my phone, heart pounding. The school bell will ring in twenty minutes, and my kids will be waiting at the gate, scanning the crowd for my face. I promised them I’d be there, like always, to hear about their day and walk them home. But my stomach growls, reminding me I haven’t eaten since breakfast. Traveling has made it so hard to keep kosher, but I spotted a tiny vendor a few blocks away—one of the only places I know is certified. If I go now, I can grab something quick, but I’ll be cutting it close, maybe even late. If I wait until after pickup, the vendor will be closed, and I’ll have nothing kosher to eat until tomorrow. My children expect me to be there, present and reliable. My faith expects me to honor the laws I’ve kept my whole life. I stand on the sidewalk, torn, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, unsure which part of myself to disappoint.
